title: The Gospel According to the Other Mary
text:
The Gospel According to the Other Mary is an <a href="opera">opera</a>-<a href="oratorio">oratorio</a> by the American composer <a href="John%20Adams%20%28composer%29">John Adams</a>. The world premiere took place on May 31, 2012, at the <a href="Walt%20Disney%20Concert%20Hall">Walt Disney Concert Hall</a> in Los Angeles with <a href="Gustavo%20Dudamel">Gustavo Dudamel</a> conducting the <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Philharmonic">Los Angeles Philharmonic</a> who also premiered the staged version on March 7, 2013, at the same venue.
The work focuses on the final few weeks of the life of <a href="Jesus">Jesus</a>, including his <a href="Passion%20of%20Jesus">passion</a>, from the point of view of "the other Mary", <a href="Mary%20of%20Bethany">Mary of Bethany</a> (sometimes mis-identified as <a href="Mary%20Magdalene">Mary Magdalene</a>), her sister <a href="Martha">Martha</a>, and her brother, <a href="Lazarus%20of%20Bethany">Lazarus</a>. The <a href="libretto">libretto</a> by <a href="Peter%20Sellars">Peter Sellars</a> draws its texts from the <a href="Old%20Testament">Old Testament</a> and <a href="New%20Testament">New Testament</a> of the <a href="Bible">Bible</a> and from <a href="Rosario%20Castellanos">Rosario Castellanos</a>, <a href="Rub%C3%A9n%20Dar%C3%ADo">Rubén Darío</a>, <a href="Dorothy%20Day">Dorothy Day</a>, <a href="Louise%20Erdrich">Louise Erdrich</a>, <a href="Hildegard%20von%20Bingen">Hildegard von Bingen</a>, <a href="June%20Jordan">June Jordan</a>, and <a href="Primo%20Levi">Primo Levi</a>.
"The Gospel According to the Other Mary" was a finalist for the 2014 <a href="Pulitzer%20Prize%20for%20Music">Pulitzer Prize for Music</a>.

Critical reception.
"The Gospel According to the Other Mary" has received widespread praise, having been variously described as "powerfully prescient", "uncommonly provocative", and "immensely powerful". Andrew Clements of "<a href="The%20Guardian">The Guardian</a>" called the score "easily the finest thing [Adams] has composed in more than two decades". Adam's orchestration in particular (notably the use of the <a href="cimbalom">cimbalom</a>) has also been hailed as inventive and effective. The Passover Aria is often celebrated by critics, and has been described by Mark Swed of the "<a href="Los%20Angeles%20Times">Los Angeles Times</a>" as "stunning exquisiteness".
However, such praise has not been universal. Comparing the piece to Adams' opera <a href="El%20Ni%C3%B1o%20%28opera%29">"El Niño"</a>, Zachary Woolfe of "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>" called "The Gospel According to the Other Mary" "more crowded and less coherent", and the piece has been described as having dramaturgical flaws by multiple critics.
